text:
Tawanda’s Toys is having a contest. Customers receive a scratch-off prize card.

  • Each card has five silver spots. If you scratch a spot, it reveals the name of an electronic game.
  • Exactly two spots match on each card.
  • A customer may scratch off only two spots on a card.
  • If the spots match, the customer wins that electronic game.

Since we cannot go to Tawada’s Toys to get some cards, we can design an experiment to simulate scratching the real cards. We need to use a model with the same characteristics as the prize cards. We can also determine the theoretical probabilities.
• Design and carry out a simulation to find the experimental probability of getting a match. Then use what you found to estimate the experimental probability of winning.

Answers will vary.

If a large number of trials was conducted, the experimental probability of winning a prize should be close to 1/10.

Simulations might include:

  • 5 cards with two that match. Cards are face down and a player picks 2.
  • 2 green blocks, 1 red block, 1 blue block, 1 yellow block in a container. A player picks 2.
  • Roll a number cube. 1 represents scratching the 1st spot, 2 represents scratching the 2nd spot, 3 represents scratching the 3rd spot, etc. If six is rolled, roll again. Roll until you get two unique numbers (because you cannot scratch off the same spot more than once.) The two unique numbers determine the spots scratched off.
• What is the theoretical probability of winning? Explain your strategy. How does the theoretical probability compare to the experimental probability?

There are 10 equally likely outcomes (pairs of spots). Of these outcomes, only one is the pair of matching spots. The probability of winning the game is 1/10.

If a large number of trials was conducted, the experimental probability of winning a prize should be close to 1/10.

Students may use different strategies to find the theoretical probability. Since the order that you scratch the spots does not matter, it will change the look of some of the strategies.

Note that if students include the repeats, the probabilities will be equivalent ratios of the non-repeats. For example, P(Scratching spots 2, 3 or 3, 2) = 2/20 = 1/10.
